title: Is This Normal?

content: A lot of people are uncomfortable talking about their digestive health, especially when it comes to what happens behind the bathroom door. But who among us hasn’t privately wondered whether something we’re experiencing is, well, normal?

Obviously, everyone is different. What’s “normal” for one person may not be for another. And you should always talk to your doctor about concerns you have. (Don’t worry about being embarrassed, they’ve heard it all!) This is especially important when something about your digestive health has changed.
In the meantime, this info might help put your mind at ease – or give you a needed nudge to see your doctor:
Is it normal … to not have a bowel movement every day?

YES. Contrary to popular belief, having a bowel movement every day isn’t necessary for good health. And skipping days doesn’t automatically mean you’re constipated. For some people, having one daily is normal. For others, it might be three to four times a week.

content_blocks.text: A lot of people are uncomfortable talking about their digestive health, especially when it comes to what happens behind the bathroom door. But who among us hasn’t privately wondered whether something we’re experiencing is, well, normal?

Obviously, everyone is different. What’s “normal” for one person may not be for another. And you should always talk to your doctor about concerns you have. (Don’t worry about being embarrassed, they’ve heard it all!) This is especially important when something about your digestive health has changed.
In the meantime, this info might help put your mind at ease – or give you a needed nudge to see your doctor:
Is it normal … to not have a bowel movement every day?

YES. Contrary to popular belief, having a bowel movement every day isn’t necessary for good health. And skipping days doesn’t automatically mean you’re constipated. For some people, having one daily is normal. For others, it might be three to four times a week.

content: What’s more important is whether your stools are hard and difficult to pass, you feel like you can’t empty fully, or you have fewer than three bowel movements a week. Those can all be signs of constipation.
Is it normal … to see undigested food in your stool?
YES, sometimes. Gross but true! Some high-fiber foods aren’t broken down completely during digestion and end up passing through. So you may see occasional bits of food like corn, seeds, and nuts.

But if it’s happening regularly, or your stools look greasy, talk to your doctor. It could be a sign that you’re not digesting and absorbing nutrients properly, which can occur with conditions like inflammatory bowel disease and colitis.
Is it normal … for stool to float?

YES. It likely just means you have extra gas in your system. A fiber-rich diet can produce gas as foods are broken down by gut bacteria. Excess gas in stools means they’re more likely to float than to sink.
Is it normal … for stool to be different colors?

content_blocks.text: What’s more important is whether your stools are hard and difficult to pass, you feel like you can’t empty fully, or you have fewer than three bowel movements a week. Those can all be signs of constipation.
Is it normal … to see undigested food in your stool?
YES, sometimes. Gross but true! Some high-fiber foods aren’t broken down completely during digestion and end up passing through. So you may see occasional bits of food like corn, seeds, and nuts.

But if it’s happening regularly, or your stools look greasy, talk to your doctor. It could be a sign that you’re not digesting and absorbing nutrients properly, which can occur with conditions like inflammatory bowel disease and colitis.
Is it normal … for stool to float?

YES. It likely just means you have extra gas in your system. A fiber-rich diet can produce gas as foods are broken down by gut bacteria. Excess gas in stools means they’re more likely to float than to sink.
Is it normal … for stool to be different colors?

content: YES, but some colors may indicate a problem. Most of the time, stool will be a shade of brown. Green can also be normal if you’re eating a diet high in veggies or if you experience diarrhea. Some medications can change stool color as well.

But alert your doctor if you notice your stools are white, yellow, or black, which can be signs of an underlying issue. While eating red food coloring or beets can temporarily turn stool red, this color might also indicate blood, which can be serious.
Is it normal … to have blood in your stool?

NO. Always notify your doctor if you see blood in your stool. This is a sign of a possible problem. It may be something minor, such as hemorrhoids, but it can also be a red flag of something more serious, such as bleeding in the intestines. So it’s important to let your doctor know right away.
Photo Credit: The Image Bank/Getty Images
